titleStmt.title: Territory of Washington v. John Doyle. Writ

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: Territory of Washington v. William Billings. Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In The District Court, Of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding terms at Olympia for the Counties of Mason and Thurston
The People of the Territory of Washington at the motion of John Doyle Ex parte
By the Writ of Habeas Corpus
The Petition of John Doyle to the Honorable John P Hoyt Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and Judge of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory most respectfully showith
That the said John Doyle is unlawfully restrained of his liberty by being confined in the jail of Thurston County by one William Billings the Keeper of said jail at the City of Olympia

That the cause or pretense for confining your petitioner is as follows. On the 14th day of June 1884 at the County of Mason in Washington Territory one E.F. McReavy appeared before one N J Ross a Justice of the Peace in said Mason County and falsely accused your petitioner with motioning Section 788 of the Code of Washington Territory by putting obstructions upon the track of a railway whereby the lives of persons travelling on said railway were endangered. That the said socalled railway is a wood tramway on which only cars are used. That two cars drawn by strain is used on said road. That said E F McReavy and one John Lathans and John McReavy claim to be of said wood tramway.

That said tramway is a private road way and not a public way, and is solely used by said three persons McReavy, Lathans, and McReavy, and by no one else, for the sale and only purpose of hauling logs from a point in the woods a short distance to a point on Hood's Cansal in said Mason County, for the sale and exclusive benefit of said three persons named and for no on else.
That near the place where said tramway was his said Hood's Cansal, this petitioner and
